results.headline: Crossing Borders Through Cinema
results.summary_short: In “Filmistaan,” an aspiring actor tries to bridge political differences when he is mistakenly captured by extremists.

results.headline: Missed Out on Millions, but He’s the Spartan Sort
results.summary_short: The documentary “Burt’s Buzz” profiles the bearded co-founder pictured on the Burt’s Bees line of personal care products.

results.headline: Navy Pilots Under the Gun
results.summary_short: In D M W Greer’s “Burning Blue,” Navy fighter pilots become the focus of an investigation that exposes a homosexual affair.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Burning Blue

results.headline: ‘Citizen Koch’ and the Politics of Big Money
results.summary_short: The limits of what an individual can do in the face of well-financed opposition are shown throughout this documentary, which looks at the effects of the Citizens United Supreme Court case.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Citizen Koch

results.headline: It Rocks When Girls Go Punk
results.summary_short: Three Stockholm girls set out to make a name for themselves in the late punk period in “We Are the Best!,” from Lukas Moodysson.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Are The Best!

results.headline: Village, Suffering From Cuteness, Seeks a Doctor
results.summary_short: Tickle Head, a down-on-its-luck fishing village, wants to lure a recycling plant so everyone can get jobs.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Grand Seduction

results.headline: Going Into a Taliban Stronghold
results.summary_short: “The Hornet’s Nest” follows Mike Boettcher, a broadcast journalist, embedded with American troops in Afghanistan during Operation Strong Eagle III.

results.display_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West
results.headline: A Frontier Farce From the Guy Behind ‘Family Guy’
results.summary_short: The one-man comedy juggernaut Seth MacFarlane directed himself in this western spoof.

results.headline: Saving the Earth With a Big Kaboom
results.summary_short: Kelly Reichardt’s “Night Moves” stars Jesse Eisenberg, Dakota Fanning and Peter Sarsgaard as young Oregonians plotting to blow up a dam.

results.display_title: Age of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaas
results.headline: Take a Man’s Horses, Expect a Reckoning
results.summary_short: The French film “Age of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaas,” adapted from a 19th-century German novella, pits Mads Mikkelsen, in the title role, against an unjust baron.

results.headline: Haunted by Combat, Yet Missing the Brethren
results.summary_short: In “Korengal,” a sequel to the documentary “Restrepo,” American soldiers contemplate their past battle experiences in a valley in Afghanistan.

results.headline: Feeling Tongue-Tied? Send a Manic Selfie
results.summary_short: In “Emoticon ;),” about a woman trying to get to know her boyfriend’s children, social media applications help surmount the communication problems.

results.headline: A Dirty Cop. No, Really Dirty.
results.summary_short: In “Filth,” James McAvoy plays an over-the-top Scottish police detective who is going insane while looking for a promotion.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Filth

results.headline: Searching for Her Sister, as Well as for Herself
results.summary_short: In the documentary “Elena,” Petra Costa explores the life of her sister, who moved from Brazil to New York, and later committed suicide.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Elena

results.headline: Dumped by Her Prince, So Watch Out
results.summary_short: As the title character in “Maleficent,” Angelina Jolie is the focus of a rethinking of the 1959 Disney animated film “Sleeping Beauty.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Maleficent

results.headline: When ’70s Guys Hit Their 70s
results.summary_short: P J Raval’s documentary “Before You Know It” follows three gay men — in New York, Florida and Texas — as they deal with the common issues of aging.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Before You Know It

results.display_title: The Life and Crimes of Doris Payne
results.headline: Such a Charming Old Lady, but Hide Your Diamonds
results.summary_short: The documentary “The Life & Crimes of Doris Payne” tells the story of a career criminal, a jewel thief now in her 80s, who pretends to be one of the rich in order to steal from them.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Life and Crimes of Doris Payne

results.headline: A Man Is Missing, and the Toll Is Ever-Present
results.summary_short: In “Gebo and the Shadow,” a family struggles with a relative’s long disappearance.

results.headline: Family Memoir in a Dreamscape
results.summary_short: The arrival of Alejandro Jodorowsky’s new feature would be grounds for excitement even if the movie, “The Dance of Reality,” were not something very close to a masterpiece.

results.display_title: Stand Clear of the Closing Doors
results.headline: A Boy Lost in the Underworld
results.summary_short: “Stand Clear of the Closing Doors,” set largely in New York City’s subway system, observes the world through the eyes of a boy with autism.
